spec.title: CSS Custom Properties for Cascading Variables Module Level 1

algorithms.name: substitute a var()
algorithms.html: To <dfn class="dfn-paneled has-dfn-panel" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export="" data-local-lt="substitute" data-lt="substitute a var()|var() substitution" id="substitute-a-var" role="button" aria-expanded="false" tabindex="0">substitute a var()</dfn> in a property’s value:

steps.html: If the custom property named by the first argument to the var() function is animation-tainted, and the var() function is being used in a property that is not animatable, treat the custom property as having its initial value for the rest of this algorithm.
If the value of the custom property named by the first argument to the var() function is anything but the initial value, replace the var() function by the value of the corresponding custom property.

Otherwise, if the var() function has a fallback value as its second argument, replace the var() function by the fallback value. If there are any var() references in the fallback, substitute them as well.
Otherwise, the property containing the var() function is invalid at computed-value time.

algorithms.name: invalid at computed-value time
algorithms.html: A declaration can be invalid at computed-value time if it contains a var() that references a custom property with the guaranteed-invalid value, as explained above, or if it uses a valid custom property, but the property value, after substituting its var() functions, is invalid. When this happens, the computed value is one of the following depending on the property’s type:

steps.case: The property is a non-registered custom property
steps.html: The computed value is the guaranteed-invalid value.

steps.case: The property is a registered custom property with universal syntax
steps.html: The computed value is the guaranteed-invalid value.
Either the property’s inherited value or its initial value depending on whether the property is inherited or not, respectively, as if the property’s value had been specified as the unset keyword.
